Determine the properties of the sum a+b+c when it is divisible by 6.
Examine the divisibility rules for cubed terms. Specifically, analyze the divisibility of a^3, b^3, and c^3 by 6.
Investigate how the remainder (modulus 6) of a, b, and c affects the expression a^3 + b^3 + c^3.
Use the identity a^3 + b^3 + c^3 - 3abc = (a+b+c)(a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - ab - bc - ca) to derive further relationships.
Explore the cases individually for possible values of a, b, and c mod 6 (0 through 5), and see their impact on a^3 + b^3 + c^3.
Check the divisibility by 3, a component of 6, seeing how it interacts with the cubic sums.
Combine the findings of divisibility by 2 and 3 to determine the overall divisibility by 6 of a^3 + b^3 + c^3.
Evaluate whether the result from step 7 holds for all integers or if there are exceptions.
Summarize the overall relationship and condition under which a^3+b^3+c^3 is divisible by 6.

Review properties of sums and divisibility by 6, focusing on the relevance of mod 6 arithmetic.
Apply the condition that a+b+c is divisible by 6 and examine any implications or restrictions it might impose on the values a, b, and c individually.
Assess the individual cubes a^3, b^3, and c^3 and their behavior under mod 6 when a, b, and c each run through their respective residue classes modulo 6.
Analyze the sum a^3 + b^3 + c^3 under the mod 6 operations to determine congruence properties.
Combine findings to establish whether a^3 + b^3 + c^3 being divisible by 6 can be generally concluded from a + b + c being divisible by 6.

Investigate the congruences of cubes of all possible remainders modulo 6 and sum these results.
